Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Blockchain-backed system that establishes the provenance of digital images and videos
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project explores translation of a media authentication technology. In an increasingly digitized world, this technology allows for anyone to instantly check the authenticity of an image or video. This technology can be used in a number of applications, such as verification of video recordings, copyright management, supply chain management, chain-of-custody processes, and other uses. <br/><br/>This I-Corps project advances the development of blockchain-backed technology to provide a visual proof of occurrence of an event. The technology frontend allows a controlled capture of images and/or videos, computes a unique signature of the media, and collects metadata such as date, time, ownership. and device identification. In the backend, a blockchain places the unique signature and meta information in a block committed upon consensus by two-thirds of the blockchain participants. Blockchain consensus guarantees the immutability of the media once the block is committed. A certified recipient can re-compute the unique signature from the file, search the blockchain for a matching block, obtain proof that the media is authentic, and instantly obtain the metadata, such as the date and time. The content creator could be anonymized or copyright information can be validated.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the spring of 2020, the eWitness team participated in the first online cohort of the NSF iCorp training program. Despite the remote format, the team conducted 101 interviews over seven weeks and presented their pitch at the final video conference. The team identified multiple potential markets for their product, including law enforcement, news, and human rights organizations.

The team's final pitch focused on the potential benefits of eWitness for small and medium-sized police departments. Specifically, the team asserted that eWitness could save time and money for investigators, empower eyewitnesses, and help to close cases more quickly. However, in the years that followed, the team continued to investigate the market fit of eWitness in both law enforcement and journalism. Through attending conferences and events and interviewing potential customers and decision makers, the team discovered that eWitness may have a stronger fit in the news industry.

Although law enforcement may be the more profitable market, the team realized that it would be best to approach that market through police technology vendors rather than direct interaction with police departments. On the other hand, grassroots journalism presented a more impactful and compelling use case for the technology, particularly in the face of the widespread dissemination of misinformation on online platforms. As a result, the team has secured additional funding to build a prototype and explore the use of eWitness in grassroots journalism.

The eWitness technology is now patent-protected and available for download on Google Play as "eWitness for social activism." With over 100 downloads to date, the team is gearing up to launch a new test in Georgia, which will explore how the technology can improve healthcare access for rural Georgians.
